qas.question: How many Jews lived in the Bronx in 1937?
How many Jews lived in the Bronx in 2011?
What led to the Bronx's population growth?

answers.text: Extensions of the New York City Subway

qas.question: What immigrant groups were the most prevalent in the Bronx?

answers.text: Irish Americans, Italian Americans and especially Jewish Americans

qas.question: How much of the Bronx was Jewish in 1937?

context: The Bronx underwent rapid urban growth after World War I. <a2_0>Extensions of the New York City Subway<a2_0/> contributed to the increase in population as thousands of immigrants came to the Bronx, resulting in a major boom in residential construction. Among these groups, many <a3_0>Irish Americans, Italian Americans and especially Jewish Americans<a3_0/> settled here. In addition, French, German, Polish and other immigrants moved into the borough. The Jewish population also increased notably during this time. In 1937, according to Jewish organizations, <a0_0>592,185<a0_0/> Jews lived in The Bronx (<a4_0>43.9%<a4_0/> of the borough's population), while only <a1_0>54,000<a1_0/> Jews lived in the borough in 2011. Many synagogues still stand in the Bronx, but most have been converted to other uses.
